/swpf/Hindrances/All-Thumbs-Minor.content:
ALL THUMBS (MINOR)
Due to upbringing, lack of exposure, or pure bad luck, some individuals are ‚Äúall thumbs‚Äù when it comes to mechanical or technological devices. All Thumbs inflicts a ‚àí2 penalty when using mechanical or electrical devices. If the hero rolls a Critical Failure while using such a device (and it doesn‚Äôt already have a built-in effect), it‚Äôs broken. If the GM feels it‚Äôs appropriate, it can be fixed with a Repair roll and 1d6 hours of work.

/swpf/Hindrances/Ancestral-Weakness-Mino.content:
ANCESTRAL WEAKNESS (MINOR/MAJOR)
Some families can trace their bloodline back far enough to find an ancestor who was from another plane. Every so often, a descendant is born with a strange weakness or trait tied to this long forgotten ancestor.
Select one of the following: Fire, Cold, or Electricity. With the Minor version of this Hindrance this character suffers +2 damage from attacks of this type. The Major version increases this to +4 damage.

/swpf/Hindrances/Anemic-Minor.content:
ANEMIC (MINOR)
Anemic characters are particularly susceptible to sickness, disease, environmental effects, and some poisons. They subtract 2 from Vigor rolls made to resist poison, disease, and Fatigue from environmental hazards (see page 151).

/swpf/Hindrances/Arrogant-Major.content:
ARROGANT (MAJOR)
Arrogant heroes don‚Äôt think they are the best‚Äî they know it. Whether it‚Äôs swordsmanship, oration or painting, these characters flaunt their prowess every chance they get. Winning isn‚Äôt enough for this champion. She wants to dominate opponents and prove there‚Äôs no one better. Arrogant individuals look for the greatest threat in battle, taking on lesser minions only because they‚Äôre in the way.

/swpf/Hindrances/Bad-Eyes-Major-or-Minor.content:
BAD EYES (MINOR OR MAJOR)
Your hero‚Äôs eyes aren‚Äôt what they used to be. The character suÔ¨Äers a ‚àí1 penalty to any Trait roll dependent on vision at a distance greater than 5" (10 yards), or ‚àí2 as a Major Hindrance. If eyeglasses are available, they negate the penalty when worn. If lost or broken during a combat (generally a 50% chance when he‚Äôs Wounded, falls, or suffers some other trauma), the character is Distracted (and Vulnerable if a Major Hindrance) until the end of his next turn.

/swpf/Hindrances/Bad-Luck-Major.content:
BAD LUCK (MAJOR)
Your hero is a little less lucky than most, getting one less Benny per game session than normal. A character cannot have both Bad Luck and the Luck Edge.

/swpf/Hindrances/Big-Mouth-Minor.content:
BIG MOUTH (MINOR)
Loose lips sink ships, the saying goes. This hero‚Äôs mouth could drown an armada. These blabbermouths can‚Äôt keep a secret very well. They reveal plans and give away things best kept among friends, usually at the worst possible times.

/swpf/Hindrances/Bitter-Major-APG.content:
BITTER (MAJOR)
You have been hurt repeatedly by those you trusted, and it has become difficult for you to accept help.
Other people attempting to heal this character suffer a ‚àí2 penalty to their roll. This applies to both mundane and magical healing. This does not affect natural healing rolls.

/swpf/Hindrances/Blind-Major.content:
BLIND (MAJOR)
The individual is completely without sight, and suffers a ‚àí6 to all physical tasks that require vision (GM‚Äôs call). On the plus side, Blind characters gain their choice of a free Edge to compensate for this particularly difficult Hindrance.

/swpf/Hindrances/Bloodthirsty-Major.content:
BLOODTHIRSTY (MAJOR)
Your hero never takes prisoners unless under the direct supervision of a superior. This cold-blooded ruthlessness causes enemies to respond in kind, which often costs vital information, creates constant enemies, and may get the hero (and companions) in trouble with superiors or the authorities.

/swpf/Hindrances/Cant-Swim-Minor.content:
CAN‚ÄôT SWIM (MINOR)
On Golarion, people who weren‚Äôt raised around a temperate body of water aren't likely to know how to swim. Those with this Hindrance suffer a ‚àí2 penalty to the Athletics skill when swimming, and each inch moved in water costs 3‚Ä≥ of Pace. See Movement (page 123) for more details and Drowning (page 151).

/swpf/Hindrances/Cautious-Minor.content:
CAUTIOUS (MINOR)
These planners personify restraint and carefulness. They never make rash decisions, preferring to plot things out in detail long before any action is taken.

/swpf/Hindrances/Clueless-Major.content:
CLUELESS (MAJOR)
Clueless heroes don‚Äôt pay much attention to the world around them and can‚Äôt seem to find a haystack in a small pile of needles. The character suffers a ‚àí1 penalty to Common Knowledge and Notice rolls.

/swpf/Hindrances/Clumsy-Major.content:
CLUMSY (MAJOR)
Your hero is uncoordinated and often stumbles over her own feet. Subtract 2 from Athletics and Stealth rolls.

/swpf/Hindrances/Code-of-Honor-Major.content:
CODE OF HONOR (MAJOR)
Honor is very important to your character. She keeps her word, doesn‚Äôt abuse or kill prisoners, and generally tries to treat others with due respect. She may have a prescribed code of conduct in line with the mores of a particular deity, cause, or social order.

/swpf/Hindrances/Constricted-Minor-APG.content:
CONSTRICTED (MINOR)
Some people can't handle the restrictive and confining nature of armor. The tight grip of leather and suffocating helms cause them to panic.
This character gains Armor Restriction (Medium) on one of her Class Edges. If she already has an Armor Restriction from another source, increase her existing Restriction (Medium is increased to Light and Light is increased to Any) to a max of Armor Restriction (Any).

/swpf/Hindrances/Curious-Major.content:
CURIOUS (MAJOR)
It killed the cat, and it might kill your hero as well. Curious characters stick their nose in others' business and always want to know what‚Äôs behind a potential mystery or secret.

/swpf/Hindrances/Death-Wish-Minor.content:
DEATH WISH (MINOR)
Having a death wish doesn‚Äôt mean an adventurer is suicidal‚Äîhe might just think his life is worth less than some noble but clearly deadly goal. Those with a Death Wish don‚Äôt throw their lives away for no reason, but when there‚Äôs a chance to complete a goal they do anything‚Äî and take any risk‚Äîto achieve it.

/swpf/Hindrances/Delusional-Minor-or-Maj.content:
DELUSIONAL (MINOR OR MAJOR)
Your hero believes something considered quite strange by most others. Minor Delusions are harmless or the character generally keeps it to himself (the magistrate puts sleeping powder in the water supply, dogs can talk, we‚Äôre all just characters in some bizarre game, etc.).
With a Major Delusion, the hero expresses opinions on the situation frequently and it can occasionally lead to danger (all potions are deadly, armor gives me hives, zombies are my friends).

/swpf/Hindrances/Driven-Minor-or-Major.content:
DRIVEN (MINOR OR MAJOR)
A vow is a commitment to others‚Äîdriven characters want something for themselves. It may be to protect the realm, prove you‚Äôre the best knucklebones player in the kingdom, or the best equestrian on Golarion.
The Minor version shapes the character and influences decisions but either happens rarely or is fairly harmless. As a Major Hindrance it‚Äôs an overriding desire that comes up frequently or causes peril for the hero and companions.

/swpf/Hindrances/Elderly-Major.content:
ELDERLY (MAJOR)
Your adventurer is getting on in years. Reduce Pace by 1 and subtract 1 from running rolls (minimum 1). Elderly characters also suffer a ‚àí1 penalty to Agility, Strength, and Vigor rolls, but not their linked skills.
On the plus side, the wisdom of years grants the hero 5 extra skill points which may be used for any skills linked to Smarts.

/swpf/Hindrances/Enemy-Minor-or-Major.content:
ENEMY (MINOR OR MAJOR)
Someone out there hates the character and wants him ruined, locked away, or dead. The value of the Hindrance depends on how powerful the enemy is and how often they might show up. A Minor Enemy might be a lone warrior out for vengeance or a betrayed brotherhood that‚Äôs deadly but appears rarely. A Major Enemy might represent powerful authorities, a band of ruffians, or a single very powerful and relentless rival. If the enemy is one day defeated, the GM should gradually work in a replacement, or the hero may buy off the Hindrance by sacrificing an Advance.

/swpf/Hindrances/Favoured-Class-Minor-or.content:
FAVORED CLASS (MINOR/MAJOR)
Whenever your hero commits to something, she sees it through to the end, even to the exclusion of other studies.
A character with the Minor version selects one core Class Edge. Increase all Trait Requirements one die type for all other Class Edges and Prestige Edges. A character with the Major version of this Hindrance can only have one core Class Edge and cannot take any Prestige Edges.

/swpf/Hindrances/Fey-taken-Minor-APG.content:
FEY‚ÄìTAKEN (MINOR)
As a child, you were whisked away by mischievous fey for a time. When you returned, you were ever after considered odd and distant. You long to return there, and find the mortal world dull and at times revolting, so you eat poorly and trust strange visions. 
The character suffers a ‚àí2 penalty on rolls to resist disease and poison and on rolls to resist spells, abilities, and opposed Tests from Fey.

/swpf/Hindrances/Greedy-Minor-or-Major.content:
GREEDY (MINOR OR MAJOR)
A miser measures worth in material possessions or wealth. If a Minor Hindrance, the character argues bitterly for more than a fair share of any loot or reward the party might come across. As a Major Hindrance, he fights over anything that seems unfair, and may even kill for it.

/swpf/Hindrances/Habit-Minor-or-Major.content:
HABIT (MINOR OR MAJOR)
Your warrior has an annoying or dangerous compulsion. A Minor Habit irritates companions but isn‚Äôt dangerous. Maybe the character picks her nose, can‚Äôt stop fiddling with some item, says ‚Äúummm‚Äù in the middle of every sentence, or chews food with her mouth open.
A Major Habit is a physical or mental addiction of some sort that is debilitating or possibly even deadly. This includes drug use, chronic drinking, or even a penchant for gambling with money stolen from allies. An addict who doesn‚Äôt get his fix must make a Vigor roll every 24 hours he goes without or take a level of Fatigue (see page 132).
Once every 24 hours, a Healing roll with some sort of appropriate medicine removes one level of Fatigue for four hours. After that the Fatigue returns and can only be recovered with the addicting substance.

/swpf/Hindrances/Hard-of-Hearing-Minor-o.content:
HARD OF HEARING (MINOR OR MAJOR)
As a Minor Hindrance, characters who've lost some of their hearing subtract 4 from Notice rolls made where hearing is involved. A Major Hindrance means the character is deaf. She cannot hear and automatically fails all Notice rolls that depend on being able to detect sound.

/swpf/Hindrances/Helpless-Minor-or-Major.content:
HELPLESS (MINOR/MAJOR)
You once stood helpless as great harm befell a loved one, and that paralysis sometimes returns when an ally is in a dire position. 
As a Minor Hindrance, whenever this character sees an ally suffers a Wound, he is Distracted. As a Major Hindrance, the character is also Vulnerable.

/swpf/Hindrances/Heroic-Major.content:
HEROIC (MAJOR)
This noble soul never says no to a person in need. She doesn‚Äôt have to be happy about it, but will always come to the rescue of those who can‚Äôt help themselves. She's the first one to run into a burning building, usually agrees to hunt monsters for little or no pay, and is generally a pushover for a sob story.

/swpf/Hindrances/Hesitant-Minor.content:
HESITANT (MINOR)
Your hero hesitates in stressful situations. Draw two Action Cards in combat and act on the lowest. If you draw a Joker, use it normally and ignore the Hindrance for the round (hence this being a Minor Hindrance, it actually increases your chances of drawing a Joker!) Hesitant characters cannot take the Quick or Level Headed Edges.

/swpf/Hindrances/Illiterate-Minor.content:
ILLITERATE (MINOR)
Your hero can't read. Perhaps he can sign his name or make his mark or recognize a single common word, but little else. He also knows very little math. He can probably figure 2 + 2 = 4, but multiplication and the like are beyond the pale.
Illiterate characters can‚Äôt read or write in any language, by the way, no matter how many they actually speak.

/swpf/Hindrances/Impulsive-Major.content:
IMPULSIVE (MAJOR)
These daredevils almost always leap before they look. They rarely think things through before taking action, avoid complicated plans, and are at the head of any charge.

/swpf/Hindrances/Jealous-Minor-or-Major.content:
JEALOUS (MINOR OR MAJOR)
Insecurity leads to envy of others‚Äô accomplishments or belongings. Such individuals complain, pout, and claim credit for other‚Äôs accomplishments.
As a Minor Hindrance, the character‚Äôs jealousy is focused on one particular subject (such as an ‚Äúunrivaled‚Äù skill or a romantic interest), or comes up rarely. As a Major Hindrance, the character is jealous of anyone and everyone that outshines them. He consistently bad-mouths rivals, tries to upstage them, or actively plots to discredit anyone who threatens his ego.

/swpf/Hindrances/Loner-Major-APG.content:
LONER (MAJOR)
Raised by pirates, bandits, or other troublemakers unwilling to stick out their necks for you, you are accustomed to operating on your own. The presence of allies can easily become a distraction, and you do your best to keep them out of your space.
This character does not benefit from Gang Up bonuses.

/swpf/Hindrances/Loyal-Minor.content:
LOYAL (MINOR)
This stalwart defender risks her life for friends without hesitation. Some Loyal heroes may not act very nice, but are the first to come to their friends‚Äô rescue when they‚Äôre threatened.

/swpf/Hindrances/Magical-Klutz-Minor-APG.content:
MAGICAL KLUTZ (MINOR)
You were born in a place with a plethora of strangely interacting magic, and magic is dangerously eager to surge into action around you. Because of this, you must take extra care when using magic items, so they don't malfunction and cause you harm.
Activating a magical item is a limited action instead of an action. If the magic item normally required a limited action, the character cannot take a Multi-Action.

/swpf/Hindrances/Mean-Minor.content:
MEAN (MINOR)
This curmudgeon is ill-tempered and disagreeable. He has trouble doing anything kind for anyone else, must be paid for services, and doesn‚Äôt accept awards or favors graciously. Besides the obvious roleplaying issues, Mean characters subtract 1 from Persuasion rolls.

/swpf/Hindrances/Meticulous-Minor-APG.content:
METICULOUS (MINOR)
You plan and prepare everything in detail, and aren‚Äôt good at improvising when things don‚Äôt go as planned.
This Pathfinder suffers ‚àí4 penalty on untrained skill rolls instead of the usual ‚àí2.

/swpf/Hindrances/Mild-Mannered-Minor.content:
MILD MANNERED (MINOR)
Your milquetoast just isn‚Äôt threatening. Maybe the hero is a little doughy around the middle, has a kind face, or a soft voice. Whatever the issue, the character subtracts 2 when making Intimidation rolls.

/swpf/Hindrances/Mundane-Vision-Minor-AP.content:
MUNDANE VISION (MINOR)
Something has caused you to lose the supernatural vision common to your ancestry. This is often caused by a curse, illness, or similar effect.
The character loses his low-light vision or darkvision. He must have low-light vision or darkvision to take this Hindrance.

/swpf/Hindrances/Mute-Major.content:
MUTE (MAJOR)
Due to trauma or birth, your character has lost the ability to speak. She can write messages to others when needed, use sign language, or some combination of visual communication, but can't form or pronounce words.
Vision-based communication may require a Notice roll to perceive correctly (illumination and similar penalties apply).

/swpf/Hindrances/Obese-Minor.content:
OBESE (MINOR)
Those who carry their weight well have the Brawny Edge. Those who don‚Äôt might be Obese. A character cannot be both Brawny and Obese, and this Hindrance can‚Äôt increase your Size above +3.
An Obese hero‚Äôs Size (and therefore Toughness) increase by +1. Reduce Pace by 1, and decrease the running die one die type (minimum d4). Strength is considered one die type less (minimum d4) for armor and worn gear (not weapons). The hero may also have difficulty finding armor or clothing that fits or entering confined spaces‚ÄîGM's call, but tight dungeon corridors, twisting caverns, and the like are all likely to cause the hero problems.

/swpf/Hindrances/Obligation-Minor-or-Maj.content:
OBLIGATION (MINOR OR MAJOR)
Your hero has a responsibility he attends to on a regular basis. He might have a job, volunteer at the local temple, take care of friends or family, and so on.
The Obligation consumes about 20 hours most weeks, or 40+ for the Major version. Exactly what that entails should be discussed between the player and the Game Master.

/swpf/Hindrances/Oblivious-Minor-APG.content:
OBLIVIOUS (MINOR)
Your hero has difficulty noticing the scope of area attacks. This character takes half damage when he makes a successful Evasion roll.

/swpf/Hindrances/One-Arm-Major.content:
ONE ARM (MAJOR)
By birth or battle, your hero has lost an arm. Fortunately, the other arm is (now) the ‚Äúgood‚Äù one. Tasks that require two hands, such as some Athletics rolls (GM‚Äôs call) or using a two-handed weapon, suffer a ‚àí4 penalty.

/swpf/Hindrances/One-Eye-Major.content:
ONE EYE (MAJOR)
This character lost an eye and has trouble with depth perception. Subtract 2 from any Trait roll dependent on vision and more than 5‚Ä≥ (10 yards) distant.

/swpf/Hindrances/Outsider-Minor-or-Major.content:
OUTSIDER (MINOR OR MAJOR)
For reasons having little or nothing to do with the character‚Äôs actions or behavior, she isn‚Äôt accepted in many societies on Golarion. Locals are likely to raise prices on the individual, ignore pleas for help, and generally treat her poorly.
Outsiders subtract 2 from Persuasion rolls made to influence those who aren‚Äôt their own kind. The Major version means most locals are Unfriendly and bullies are likely to pick fights with her.

/swpf/Hindrances/Overconfident-Major.content:
OVERCONFIDENT (MAJOR)
There‚Äôs nothing out there your hero can‚Äôt defeat. At least that‚Äôs what she thinks. She believes she can do most anything and never wants to retreat from a challenge. She's not suicidal, but certainly takes on more than common sense dictates.

/swpf/Hindrances/Pacifist-Minor-or-Major.content:
PACIFIST (MINOR OR MAJOR)
Your hero absolutely despises violence. Minor pacifism means the hero fights only when given no other choice and never allows the killing of prisoners or other defenseless victims.
Major Pacifists won‚Äôt fight living characters under any circumstances. They may defend themselves, but won‚Äôt do anything to permanently harm sapient, living beings. They may use nonlethal methods (see page 136), but only in self-defense or the defense of others.
Note that undeniably evil creatures, undead, demons and the like are fair game even for Major Pacifists.

/swpf/Hindrances/Phobia-Minor-or-Major.content:
PHOBIA (MINOR OR MAJOR)
Phobias are overwhelming and irrational fears that plague a hero‚Äôs psyche. Whenever a character is in the presence of the phobia (GM‚Äôs call, but generally sight), subtract 1 from all Trait rolls for a Minor Hindrance and 2 for a Major. 
Phobias shouldn‚Äôt be too obvious; everyone should be afraid of vampires, for example, so it‚Äôs not a phobia, it‚Äôs common sense. Instead, the phobia usually centers on some random element the mind associates with the event. Remember, phobias are irrational fears.

/swpf/Hindrances/Poverty-Minor.content:
POVERTY (MINOR)
It‚Äôs said fools and their money are soon parted. Your hero is one of them. The character starts with half the usual starting funds and just can‚Äôt seem to hang on to funds acquired after play begins. In general, the character halves the total funds every game week.

/swpf/Hindrances/Quirk-Minor.content:
QUIRK (MINOR)
This individual has some minor foible that is usually humorous but can occasionally cause real trouble. A swashbuckler may always try to slash a mark on foes, a dwarf may brag constantly about dwarven culture, or a snobby d√©butante might not eat, drink, or socialize with the lower class, for example.

/swpf/Hindrances/Ruthless-Minor-or-Major.content:
RUTHLESS (MINOR OR MAJOR)
These fanatics will do most anything to accomplish their goals. As a Major Hindrance, Ruthless characters are willing to harm anyone who gets in the way. As a Minor Hindrance, these heroes stop short of true harm to anyone except those who directly oppose them.

/swpf/Hindrances/Secret-Minor-or-Major.content:
SECRET (MINOR OR MAJOR)
Your hero keeps a secret to protect himself or others. As a Minor Hindrance, the secret is troublesome or embarrassing but not life-threatening.
The Major version would cause severe problems if discovered. If it ever becomes public knowledge, he should trade this Hindrance for Enemy, Shamed, Wanted, or another appropriate Hindrance approved by the GM.

/swpf/Hindrances/Shamed-Minor-or-Major.content:
SHAMED (MINOR OR MAJOR)
Something haunts your adventurer. Maybe the hero failed to keep a Vow. Maybe the character was defeated in an honorable fight and ordered the death of the foe anyway for some greater principle. Maybe the hero isn‚Äôt actually cowardly but once ran from a battle and left others to die.
As a Minor Hindrance, the shameful circumstances aren‚Äôt generally known‚Äî it just haunts him. He might go out of his way, against all reason, not to repeat the mistake. Or he might give in to the same set of circumstances and hate himself for it.
As a Major Hindrance, the ill deed is wellknown ‚Äî or at least known among those the hero cares about. The other player characters should be told the tale as soon as possible (preferably at character creation). If not, it should be revealed by nonplayer characters at some point, and occasionally used against the hero.

/swpf/Hindrances/Short-Sighted-Minor-or-.content:
SHORT SIGHTED (MINOR OR MAJOR)
Some adventurers see things through to the end. Pulling at every thread, they won't consider something finished until they've exhausted every option. This is not your hero.
A character with the Minor version of this Hindrance cannot spend Conviction to gain an extra use of once per encounter, session or day abilities. The Major version of this Hindrance allows Conviction to be spent for additional uses of abilities but makes the Conviction die a d4.

/swpf/Hindrances/Slow-Minor-or-Major.content:
SLOW (MINOR OR MAJOR)
A disability or past injury has hindered this adventurer's mobility. As a Minor Hindrance, reduce Pace by 1 and the running die one step (if already d4, reduce to d4 ‚àí 1 ). As a Major Hindrance, reduce the running die a step, reduce Pace by 2, and subtract 2 from Athletics rolls and rolls to resist Athletics (such as Tests or Grappling).
Slow characters may not take the Fleet- Footed Edge.
**Prosthesis:** A character with the Minor version of this Hindrance may have a prosthesis. If the prosthesis is lost, he suffers the effects of the Major version of Slow.
**Wheelchairs:** Wheelchairs are available in more enlightened areas of Golarion. Slow heroes may start with a manual wheelchair at no cost (100 gp to replace thereafter). Wheelchairs require reasonably smooth ground to operate on and have a Pace equal to half the user's Athletics die (max of 3, he cannot run).

/swpf/Hindrances/Small-Minor.content:
SMALL (MINOR)
This adventurer is very skinny, very short, or both. Size (see page 138) is reduced by 1, which reduces Toughness as well. A player character's Size can‚Äôt be reduced below ‚àí1, but the Toughness penalty remains. A Small halfling, for example, remains Size ‚àí1 and loses a point of Toughness.

/swpf/Hindrances/Spooked-Minor-APG.content:
SPOOKED (MINOR)
A traumatic experience at a young age with a spirit, undead, or other supernatural entity colors your reactions to such creatures.
Whenever you perceive a Fey, Outsider, or Undead within 10" (20 yards) you must make a Fear check. If the creature innately causes Fear, you suffer an additional ‚àí2 to the Fear check. The character does not need to make an additional Fear check if the creature has Fear.

*When a character becomes Jaded (see Pathfinder for Savage Worlds) against a creature's Fear, it only applies to a specific Fey, Outsiders, or Undead. A character may stop being fearful of his tiefling companion, but still panic when he sees a vrock. This means the more supernatural creatures this character is exposed to, the less he will be affected.*

/swpf/Hindrances/Stubborn-Minor.content:
STUBBORN (MINOR)
Stubborn individuals always want their way and never admit they‚Äôre wrong. Even when it‚Äôs painfully obvious they‚Äôve made a mistake they try to justify it with half-truths and rationalizations.

/swpf/Hindrances/Suspicious-Minor-or-Maj.content:
SUSPICIOUS (MINOR OR MAJOR)
Your character is suspicious of everyone. As a Minor Hindrance, this paranoia causes frequent trust issues. Suspicious characters might demand full payment before doing a task, want every agreement in writing, or believe even friends are out to get them. As a Major Hindrance, Support rolls to aid the distrustful individual are made at ‚àí2.

/swpf/Hindrances/Tainted-Spirit-Major-AP.content:
TAINTED SPIRIT (MAJOR)
As a child, a parent or other person with authority over you made a pact with a fiend, stealing some of your vitality as collateral. Immediately after combat ends, this character makes a Vigor roll or suffers a level of Fatigue. This Fatigue lasts until the character spends 24 hours without getting into combat.

/swpf/Hindrances/Thin-Skinned-Minor-or-M.content:
THIN SKINNED (MINOR OR MAJOR)
Personal attacks really get under this individual‚Äôs skin. As a Minor Hindrance, subtract 2 when resisting Taunt attacks. As a Major, subtract 4.

/swpf/Hindrances/Timid-Major.content:
TIMID (MAJOR)
Not everyone has ice water in their veins. Your hero is squeamish at the sight of blood and gore and terrified of coming to harm. Subtract 2 from Fear checks as well as rolls to resist Intimidation.

/swpf/Hindrances/Tongue-Tied-Major.content:
TONGUE-TIED (MAJOR)
Your adventurer flubs cool lines (or thinks of them afterwards!), goes off on tangents when trying to talk someone into something, and generally miscommunicates most everything they say.
The hero suffers a ‚àí1 penalty to Intimidation, Performance, Persuasion, and Taunt rolls that involve speech.

/swpf/Hindrances/Ugly-Minor-or-Major.content:
UGLY (MINOR OR MAJOR)
Attractive people get all the breaks. This unfortunate individual isn‚Äôt one of them. The character subtracts 1 from Persuasion rolls, or 2 if taken as a Major Hindrance.

/swpf/Hindrances/Umbral-Unmasking-Minor-.content:
UMBRAL UNMASKING (MINOR)
You cast no shadow whatsoever, or the shadow you do have is monstrous. Under normal lighted conditions, this is not hard to observe‚Äîbut uncommon to notice.
Anyone who notices this character's shadow has a worse initial reaction to the character (see Persuasion in Pathfinder for Savage Worlds).

/swpf/Hindrances/Vengeful-Minor-or-Major.content:
VENGEFUL (MINOR OR MAJOR)
Payback is‚Ä¶well‚Ä¶bad news for someone, and this adventurer is going to get it. 
As a Minor Hindrance, the hero usually seeks vengeance legally. The method varies by situation. Some plot and scheme for months while others demand immediate results. 
Those with the Major version of this Hindrance won‚Äôt let anything prevent them from a reckoning. This doesn‚Äôt mean they immediately resort to violence, but their actions always escalate until total and complete satisfaction is achieved.

/swpf/Hindrances/Vow-Minor-or-Major.content:
VOW (MINOR OR MAJOR)
The character has sworn an oath to someone or something they believe in.
The danger in fulfilling the Vow and how often it might occur determines the level of the Hindrance. A Minor Vow might be to serve an order with a broad mandate that rarely conflicts with the party‚Äôs goals.  
A Major Vow makes long-term and frequent demands on the servant‚Äôs time and results in great risks to his life.

/swpf/Hindrances/Wanted-Minor-or-Major.content:
WANTED (MINOR OR MAJOR)
Your hero has committed some crime and will be arrested if discovered by the authorities. The level of the Hindrance depends on how serious the crime was and how active the hunters are. A hero accused of theft may have only a Minor Hindrance, as might someone wanted for more serious crimes away from the main campaign area.
Being accused of murder is a Major Hindrance in the ‚Äúcivilized‚Äù societies on Golarion if there‚Äôs someone around to seek justice (or vengeance).

/swpf/Hindrances/Warded-Against-Nature-M.content:
WARDED AGAINST NATURE (MINOR)
Animals find your character particularly unnerving. Even the most well trained animals require coaxing to work with you.
Animals do not willingly approach within 10" (20 yards) of you unless persuaded. In addition, the hero suffers a ‚àí2 penalty on rolls to control animals, including Riding (see Animal Handling, below).

/swpf/Hindrances/Young-Minor-or-Major.content:
YOUNG (MINOR OR MAJOR)
The hero is 12‚Äì15 years old (in human years‚Äî adjust this for other ancestries). He only has 4 points to adjust attributes instead of 5, and 10 skill points instead of 12. The youth may also have legal restrictions depending on any local customs (can‚Äôt drink alcohol, can‚Äôt carry a weapon, and so on).
On the plus side, youths draw one extra Benny at the beginning of each game session (this stacks with other Edges such Luck or Great Luck).
Most Young characters should also take the Small Hindrance, but it‚Äôs not mandatory.
As a Major Hindrance, the character is Very Young (8 to 11 years old), getting only 3 points for attributes and 10 for skills, along with the Small Hindrance. Very Young heroes draw two extra Bennies at the start of each session.

/swpf/Traits/Attributes/Agility.content: Agility is a measure of a character‚Äôs nimbleness, dexterity, and general coordination.

/swpf/Traits/Attributes/Smarts.content: Smarts measures raw intelligence, mental acuity, and how fast a heroine thinks on her feet. It‚Äôs used to resist certain types of mental and social attacks.

/swpf/Traits/Attributes/Spirit.content: Spirit is self-confidence, backbone, and willpower. It‚Äôs used to resist social and supernatural attacks as well as fear.

/swpf/Traits/Attributes/Strength.content: Strength is physical power and fitness. It‚Äôs also used as the basis of a warrior‚Äôs damage in hand-to-hand combat, and to determine how much he can wear or carry.

/swpf/Traits/Attributes/Vigor.content: Vigor represents an individual‚Äôs endurance, resistance to disease, poison, or toxins, and how much physical damage heroes can take before they can‚Äôt go on. It is most often used to resist Fatigue effects, and as the basis for the derived stat of Toughness.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Academics-Smarts.content:
ACADEMICS (SMARTS)
Academics reflects knowledge of the arts, history, archaeology, religion, and similar fields, or the ability to find that information. If an explorer wants to research when the Imperial Calendar began or cite a line from Azvadeva Pujila, or use his linguistic expertise to decipher a dead language, this is the skill to have.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Alchemy-Smarts-APG.content:
ALCHEMY (SMARTS)
Alchemy is a new arcane skill for the Alchemist Class Edge (see page 38).

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Animal-Handling.content:
ANIMAL HANDLING
Pathfinders must frequently train, control, ride, or otherwise attempt to get creatures of animal intelligence to do their bidding. Rather than create a new skill that might conflict with others, we use Intimidation or Persuasion, depending on approach and demeanor.
With success, the animal attempts to follow the instructions to the best of its ability. It's still just an animal though, so complex tasks are usually beyond its abilities to comprehend. Unlike influencing sentient creatures, a hero need not worry about speaking the same language as the animal. If he is able to speak to the animal, however, he adds +2 to the roll.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Athletics-Agility-Co.content:
ATHLETICS (AGILITY)
Athletics combines an individual‚Äôs coordination with learned skills such as climbing, jumping, balancing, wrestling, swimming, throwing, or catching. Characters who rely on physical power more than coordination can take the Brute Edge (page 41) to link this skill to Strength instead of Agility.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Battle-Smarts.content:
BATTLE (SMARTS)
Battle is an individual‚Äôs command of strategy and tactics. It can be used for general military knowledge and is critical when commanding troops in Mass Battles (see page 158).

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Boating-Agility.content:
BOATING (AGILITY)
Characters with this skill can handle most any common waterborne boat or ship. They also know how to handle common tasks associated with their vessel such as tying knots, rigging sails, or following currents.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Common-Knowledge-Sma.content:
COMMON KNOWLEDGE (SMARTS)
Characters roll Common Knowledge to know people, places, and things of their locale, including etiquette, geography, culture, current events, contacts, and customs.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Driving-Agility.content:
DRIVING (AGILITY)
Although rare on Golarion, Driving allows a hero to control any powered ground vehicle. Self-powered transports use Athletics, while beast-drawn conveyances use Riding. Driving rolls are typically only needed in dangerous or stressful conditions, such as chases or when navigating dangerous roads or attempting to race through crowded city streets.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Faith-Spirit.content:
FAITH (SPIRIT)
Clerics and druids use Faith as the arcane skill required for their Arcane Backgrounds, described on pages 48 and 52.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Fighting-Agility.content:
FIGHTING (AGILITY)
Fighting covers all hand-to-hand (melee) attacks, whether it‚Äôs with fists, axes, swords, or martial arts. It reflects skill as well as raw power, savagery, and fearlessness.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Gambling-Smarts.content:
GAMBLING (SMARTS)
Gambling is common in taverns, roadside inns, the barracks of most armies, or below decks of ships at sea. 
To simulate an hour of gambling without having to roll for every single toss of the dice or hand of cards, have everyone agree on the stakes, such as 10 gold coins, etc. Everyone in the game then makes a Gambling roll. The lowest total pays the highest total the difference times the stake. The next lowest pays the second highest the difference times the stake, and so on. If there‚Äôs an odd man left in the middle, he breaks even. 
**Example:** A rogue rolls highest with a 10 and the bard rolls lowest with a 4. The difference is 6, so the bard pays 6 √ó the stake of 10, or 60 gp. 
**Cheating:** A character who cheats adds +2 to his roll. The GM may raise or lower this modifier depending on the particulars of the game or the method of cheating. If a cheater rolls a Critical Failure, however, she's caught. The consequences depend on the circumstances and who noticed, but are usually unpleasant!

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Healing-Smarts.content:
HEALING (SMARTS)
Healing has multiple uses, from treating Wounds to diagnosing diseases and analyzing certain kinds of forensic evidence. 
See page 128 for rules on mending and treating Wounds, and pages 152 and 155 for treatment of disease or poison. 
Healing can also be used to analyze evidence that relates to anatomical trauma, including cause of death and approximate time, a general angle of attack, and similar matters. Success provides basic information and a raise increases the details uncovered.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Intimidation-Spirit.content:
INTIMIDATION (SPIRIT)
Intimidation is the art of frightening an opponent so that he backs down, reveals information, or flees.
Intimidation is an opposed roll resisted by the opponent‚Äôs Spirit. In combat, this is a Test (see page 140). Out of combat, a successful roll means the foe backs down for the most part, reveals some information, or slinks away when the opportunity presents itself. A raise might mean the target backs down for the remainder of the scene, spills all the beans, or runs away as fast as possible.
In or out of combat, a Critical Failure on the roll means the target is immune to this character‚Äôs Intimidation attempts for the remainder of this encounter!
**Networking:** Intimidation can also be used as a ‚Äúmacro‚Äù skill to simulate several hours of working the streets. See Networking on page 160 to see how to crack some heads for favors or information.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Notice-Smarts-Core.content:
NOTICE (SMARTS)
Notice is a hero‚Äôs general awareness and alertness. It‚Äôs used to sense sights, sounds, tastes, and smells, spot clues, detect ambushes, spot hidden weapons on a foe, or tell if a rival is lying, frightened, happy, etc.
Success conveys basic information‚Äîthe character hears movement in the forest, smells distant smoke, or senses someone isn‚Äôt being completely truthful.
A raise grants more detail, such as the direction of a sound or odor or what topic a person is avoiding or lying about.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Occult-Smarts.content:
OCCULT (SMARTS)
Occult reflects knowledge and experience of magical and supernatural events, processes, items, and creatures.
It can be used to decipher glyphs, recall information about Golarion's monsters, recall cures for supernatural maladies like lycanthropy or vampirism, and so on. Finding information in a library, a wizard‚Äôs lair, or in an old dusty tome uses the Academics skill. If the investigator‚Äôs Occult skill is higher, she may use that instead. See Academics on page 33.
Some esoteric information will be familiar to people with certain skills. If the situation warrants (and with the GM's permission), you may substitute Faith or Spellcasting in place of Occult.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Performance-Spirit.content:
PERFORMANCE (SPIRIT)
A good entertainer can lift spirits, rally a crowd to action, or simply earn a few coins from the locals. Specifics depend on the situation, setting, and how well the character is known in the area.
Performance covers singing, acting, playing an instrument, or similar tasks that require an audience to appreciate. It is also the arcane skill used by bards.
**Raising Funds:** The amount of money a character can raise by performing is extremely subjective, but as a general rule a successful performance earns 50 gp √ó the character's Rank (Novice 1, Seasoned 2, 3 for Veteran, 4 for Heroic, and 5 for Legendary). A raise doubles the amount earned.
If the performer has built up a solid reputation in the area or the venue is particularly large, the GM should increase the base gp value appropriately.
**Deception:** Performance can be used instead of Persuasion if the character is attempting to deceive, bluff, or disguise herself and the GM agrees it makes sense in the context of the situation.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Persuasion-Spirit-Co.content:
PERSUASION (SPIRIT)
Persuasion is the ability to convince others to do what you want through reason, cajoling, deception, rewards, or other friendly means. Persuasion isn‚Äôt mind control. It can change someone‚Äôs attitude but not their goals. A bandit may let you keep a sentimental piece of jewelry with a good Persuasion roll but still takes all your other goods.
When used to Support allies (page 138) it‚Äôs an unopposed roll. If the target is resistant, it‚Äôs an opposed roll vs. the target‚Äôs Spirit. The GM should modify the roll as appropriate based on roleplaying, any pertinent Edges or Hindrances that affect the conversation, and the circumstances.
**Reaction Level:** How much a person is willing to cooperate depends largely on their attitude toward whoever‚Äôs talking to them. The Game Master can decide how nonplayer characters feel based on the setting, or roll on the [[Reaction Table]]  when having no preconceived notions.
Success improves the target‚Äôs attitude one level and a raise improves it two. Further increases aren‚Äôt generally possible in the same encounter‚Äîit takes individuals a little time to adjust their biases.
Failure means the target won‚Äôt change his mind this encounter or until the situation changes in some important way. A Critical Failure also reduces the target‚Äôs attitude two levels.
Only one roll should generally be allowed per interaction unless new information is revealed, a substantial reward is offered, etc.
**Networking:** Characters can also use Persuasion as a ‚Äúmacro skill,‚Äù simulating a few hours or an evening‚Äôs time hobnobbing and socializing to gain favors or information. See Networking on page 160.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Piloting-Agility.content:
PILOTING (AGILITY)
Although rare on Golarion, Piloting allows a character to maneuver any kind of airship. A being with the innate ability to fly (having wings, for example) uses Athletics instead.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Repair-Smarts.content:
REPAIR (SMARTS)
Repair is the ability to take apart and/or fix mechanical gadgets, vehicles, weapons, and other simple devices. It also covers the use of demolitions and explosives.
How long a Repair roll takes is up to the GM and the complexity of the task. Success means the item is functional. A raise on the Repair roll halves the time required.
**Tools:** Characters suffer a minor penalty (‚àí1 to ‚àí2) to their roll if they don‚Äôt have access to basic tools, or a major penalty (‚àí3 to ‚àí4) if the device requires specialized equipment.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Riding-Agility.content:
RIDING (AGILITY)
Riding allows a hero to mount, control, and ride any beast or beast-drawn vehicle. This includes horses, camels, dragons, wagons, chariots, and the like. See the rules for Mounted Combat on page 135.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Science-Smarts.content:
SCIENCE (SMARTS)
Those with this skill have studied various disciplines from architecture to natural sciences to engineering and other ‚Äúhard‚Äù sciences.
A successful roll reveals basic information about a topic, and a raise grants more details.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Shooting-Agility.content:
SHOOTING (AGILITY)
Shooting covers all attempts to hit a target with a ranged weapon such as a bow or crossbow (thrown weapons use Athletics, page 33). See Chapter Three for details on ranged combat.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Spellcasting-Smarts.content:
SPELLCASTING (SMARTS)
Sorcerers and wizards use Spellcasting as their arcane skill when casting spells. See Chapter Five for more information on magical powers.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Stealth-Agility-Core.content:
STEALTH (AGILITY)
Stealth is the ability to hide and move quietly. A simple success on a Stealth roll means the character avoids detection if enemies aren‚Äôt particularly alert. If the character fails the roll, the enemy realizes something is amiss and begins actively searching for whatever roused them.
Once foes are alerted and active, Stealth is opposed by Notice (a group roll if there are many foes, see page 119).
The GM should apply any circumstantial penalties to Notice rolls for darkness, cover, noise, distractions, and any difference in the target‚Äôs Scale (just like when attacking, see Scale on page 138). Sneaking through dry leaves might subtract 2 from the Stealth roll, for example, while spotting someone in the dark uses the Illumination penalty listed on page 134 (‚àí4). Don‚Äôt apply the same modifier to both rolls, however. If Stealth is at ‚àí2 for the leaves, don‚Äôt give Notice a +2 for them as well. 
**Attacking from Stealth:** Sneaking up close enough to make a melee attack always requires an opposed Stealth roll versus the target‚Äôs Notice, whether the guard is actively looking for trouble or not.
If successful, the attacker is considered on Hold (page 134) and the victim is Vulnerable (page 132) to him (but not others) until the attacker‚Äôs turn ends (not the defender‚Äôs in this case). With a raise, the attacker has The Drop (page 132) instead.
Before the attacker strikes, the defender and any other beings on his side must check for Surprise (see page 139). The attacker may come off Hold and resolve his strike; then the rest of the round progresses normally.
**Movement:** In combat, characters roll Stealth each turn as a free action at the end of their move or any action the GM thinks might draw attention.
Out of combat, the distance moved depends entirely on the situation. The GM might want a roll every minute if the group is sneaking around the perimeter of a defensive position, or every few miles if they‚Äôre trying to quietly walk through a dark forest without alerting the creatures that live there.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Survival-Smarts.content:
SURVIVAL (SMARTS)
Survival allows a character to find food, water, or shelter in hostile environments. It can also be used to navigate wilderness environments, figure out which plants are good to eat and which aren‚Äôt, and so on.
A successful Survival roll provides enough food and water for one person for one day; or five people with a raise.
More detailed information on Hunger and Thirst can be found under Hazards on page 155.
**Tracking:** Survival can also be used to detect and follow tracks. Each roll generally covers following the tracks for one mile, but the GM should adjust this as needed for specific circumstances. A character moves at half Pace and cannot run while tracking a foe.
The Game Master should assign a bonus or penalty based on the target, environment, and time. Tracking a large group that recently passed through a snow-covered area might grant a bonus of +4, while following a single person over rocks and streams after more than a day incurs a ‚àí4 penalty.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Taunt-Smarts.content:
TAUNT (SMARTS)
Taunt attacks a person‚Äôs pride through ridicule, cruel jests, or oneupmanship. Taunt is an opposed roll resisted by the opponent‚Äôs Smarts. In combat, this is a Test (see page 140).
Out of combat, success means the defender backs down, slinks away, or starts a fight. A raise might leave the victim cowed for the remainder of the encounter, cause them to storm out in tears, or even make a reckless attack.
A Critical Failure on the Taunt means the target is immune to this character‚Äôs Taunts for the remainder of the encounter.

/swpf/Traits/Skills/Thievery-Agility.content:
THIEVERY (AGILITY)
Lockpicking, safecracking, picking pockets, sleight of hand, setting and disabling traps, and similar acts of misdirection, sabotage, subterfuge, and manipulation are called Thievery.
If used to pick a lock, crack a safe, disable a trap, or perform a simple unopposed action, success opens or disables the device, and a raise does it in less time, without tripping alarms, or whatever else the GM feels is appropriate.
Sleight of hand, hiding or planting an item, or picking a pocket require a simple success. If foes are actively watching the character, Thievery is opposed by Notice.
The Game Master should assign penalties for particularly difficult circumstances. Picking a heavy padlock might have a ‚àí4 penalty, while hiding a dagger in bulky winter clothing might grant a +2 bonus. Failure typically means the character is spotted or it takes too much time (after which the character can try again). A Critical Failure typically sets off the trap, alerts the victim, or jams the device so that it must be opened or interacted with in a different way.
